PROMETHEUS; OR, THE MAN ON THE ROCK A New and Original Extravaganza.

First performed at the New Royalty Theatre, (under the management of Miss Fanny Reeves), on Saturday, December 23rd, 1865, the New and Original Extravaganza, entitled PROMETHEUS; OR, THE MAN ON THE ROCK. The Music arranged by Mr. Herman. Ballet arranged by Mr. Marshall. New Scenery by Mr. H. Cuthbert. The New Costumes by Mr. May. Machinery by Mr. Smith and Assistants. The whole produced under the direction of Mr. Mowbray.

THE ARGUMENT. Prometheus, the son of Iapetus, and of the race of the Titans, the Marochetti of his age, who always had a cast in his eye, employed himself in the task of modelling humanity with the object of opposing the New Royalty of Jove who had usurped Saturn's dominions. To give life to his models, he conceived the daring design of stealing fire from the sun. For this act, Jove in a pique chained him to a crag of Caucasus, and to punish him more effectually sent him a model woman, and with her a closed box as a dowry. Prometheus, who, as he always had his clay about him smoked the trick—would have baffled Jove's design, had not his mother, in a fit of fatal curiosity, opened the box and let out all those evils which have since infested the world. The spirit of Hope, however, lurked at the bottom of the box, and on her intercession, Prometheus was released on parole for the future.

Characters. JOVE (a Usurper—founder of the New Royalty—considered as erratically erotic, but under the the rule of his Queen Juno) Mr. Connell. APOLLO (a great anomaly—being in the same capacity both Father and Sun—who suffered because he allowed his Phæton to drive his carriage) Miss Lydia Maitland. MARS (God of War—Venus's suitor, and very well he seems to suit her) Mr. Fred. Hughes. MERCURY (the Lackey of the Gods, and Call-boy of Olympus) Miss Annie Bourke. VULCAN (the real original Smith—Printer and Publisher to Olympus—for which his Cyclops published the 1st Cyclopædia—husband of Venus—see Mars) Mr. Hayes. NEPTUNE (the holder of many rich seas, which he waives for a time to officiate against Prometheus) Miss Fosbrook. PROMETHEUS (a right un and a Titan—the first philanthropist—statuary and inventor of everything, including humanity—subsequently a rebel on a gigantic scale, and Anactive enemy to Jove) Miss Fanny Reeves. JUNO (Jove's Queen, who ruled the roast, and roasted the ruler) Miss Lascelles. VENUS (Goddess of Love!—You must see her, and then!) Miss Nelly Burton. MINERVA (a strict Lady, on whose character there was no stain, it was so staid) Mr. Baildon. DIANA (the inconstant Moon—quite as useful as hornimental) Miss Atterwell. OUTIS (Prometheus's Mother, not mentioned in Mythology, but who it is reasonable to suppose did exist—the Author while he points out the Missis misses no point in supplying information to the Audience) Mr. Bentley. PANDORA (the great Unknown—a Model Woman!) Miss Brown. THE FATES, THE FURIES, AND SMALLER DIVINITIES Messrs. and Mesdms. Clotho, Atropos. &c. THE SUN HEAD (a great Luminary) Mr. Hollingsworth. HOPE. Miss Walters. THE PRIESTESS OF APOLLO Miss Healey.
Scene 1.—THE CLOUDS. Scene 2.—ROOM IN PROMETHEUS' HOUSE. Scene 3.—RECEPTION ROOM IN OLYMPUS. Scene 4.—THE PALACE OF THE SUN. Scene 5.—ROCKY SHORE AND CRAGS OF CAUCASUS.

Scene First. —The Clouds (1st grooves). Lively music. Enter Mercury, R. Merc. So far so good. Yours, toujours to command. I'm Mercury be pleased to understand; The wily god who every sense deceives, Patron of playwrights, authors, and of thieves. On secret service sent to-day. Look out, And you'll soon find out what it's all about. Enter Apollo, L. How now, Apollo? whither wander you? We haven't seen your face this week or two. Apollo. I'm on my usual circuit, which I keep, Unvarying whilst other people sleep. I am an early riser! Merc. Where's your car? Apollo. Oh, I'm still waiting for the Morning Star. (crossing to R.) Aurora drives the first stage. Well, but you, Thus far beneath the clouds, what do you do? Merc. I'm on an errand here. Apollo. From Jove? Merc. Just so. Apollo. Then I can guess; 'tis to our friend below, Prometheus. Enter a Winged Boy, R., with a paper for Apollo, which he gives, and exits, R. Merc. Yes; but pray don't call him “friend.” We don't know where his insolence will end. Apollo. Why, what's his last offence which makes Jove fear, And sends you down? Merc. We've not the least idea. But long we've watched him with some blocks of clay, Industriously working night and day. Apollo. For what? Merc. Why, that's the point we wish to know. We can't make out what makes him labour so. All night he toils, or if he rests awhile, His face is lit up with a mocking smile; And then he starts and wakes, and smiling still, Turns out, and turns to labour with a will. Apollo. 'Tis strange! This work of his you may depend, 'Gainst Jove does some conspiracy portend. Merc. (crossing to R.) And so I'm off to sift the matter out. Apollo. You'll find the task a hard one, I've no doubt. But I'll not keep you, for I'm anxious too. I think I'll call on him this morning. Merc. (red fire is seen at R. 1 E.) Do! Apollo. (crossing to R.) Ha! there's Aurora taking off the traces; So I'll decamp, just like de Camptown races. Duo.—Apollo and Mercury.—Air, “The Campbells are coming.” Merc. A truce to your punning, oh, ho, ho, ho! 'Tis no time for funning— Oh no! oh no! Apollo. So, off I'll be runnin', With all his fine cunnin', He'll not take the sun in— Oh no! no go! (repeat ensemble, dance, and exeunt, R)

Scene Second. —Room in Prometheus' House (2nd grooves); small table, with drinking flask, bowl, and spoon on it, C.; four children as clay models, on pedestals, crossing stage at back. Outis discovered dusting images—coloured fires ready to light on pedestals, upon which the children are standing. Outis. Disgusting trade! Where is this whim to stop? If matters go on thus I'll shut up shop; My health is failing 'neath each new disaster, I'm thin as lath from dabbling in this plaster. I don't know how it is, but since this week, My son's gone crazy—mad upon a freak, For manufacturing a new humanity— A most decided proof of his insanity! Each day, each night, beholds him at his toil, Soiling his fingers in the thankless soil; And all to fashion such like useless clods, Defective types of very so—so gods. (drinks) Very dry work. (rap outside) Hark! isn't that a rap? Perhaps the beer—I thought I heard a tap. Not so. (takes bottle from table) Well, here's the real Lethe tipple, Jove's own brew, not designed for common pipple. It's very odd! The more I take to drink, The more I find it difficult to think. I've nectar ta'en enough to clear my head, And yet I seem to get confused instead. Song.—Air, “Billy Barlow.” Now, it's odd, though I've taken of tumblers so few, When I look at one object, I seem to see two, And drink as I may, it's a sorrow to know, As the objects increase, so my wits seem to go. Oh! dear, how happens it so? It's a question of science I'd much like to know. Now, censorious folks might be likely to think, That, from present appearance, I'm given to drink; But should any accuse me, I'd have 'em to know, I consider intemperance not “comme il faut.” Oh! dear, certainly no— Drink was given for use, not abuse, here below. (noise outside, L. 1 E.) Ha! there's Prometheus! 'tis my son—at last. Still on his models—in his eyes a cast; With haggard cheek, rough locks, and downcast head, And light in hand—he's never been to bed. Piano, tremolo Music.—Enter Prometheus, L. 1 E., with lighted candle—walking slowly, as if in thought—when near C. of stage speaks. Prometh. To be or not to be! That is the question! (Outis blows out candle, and Music stops) I beg your pardon! What was your suggestion? Outis. Breakfast! Prometh. Away! (crosses, R.) I need no paltry food! Outis. Oh! do, Prometheus—it'll do you good. Prometh. Don't talk to me of food, prosaic griffin! (goes up and puts candle on table) Outis. I mention breakfast, and he's got a tiff in. Prometh. Repulsive being—there, take your food away! Outis. Don't let there be a food between us, pray! Prometh. (down, L.) I'll do't—I'll do't—I'll beard this upstart, Jove— His wildest flights I'll dare to soar above! Outis. That's a sore subject—you are much too flighty! Prometh. Now, listen, mother—I don't wish to fright ye, But no more on that subject—I command it! You sneer—because you do not understand it. Outis. But, son! Prometh. Away! (crosses, R.) You mar my best reflection! Outis. I mar? Prometh. Yes, ma—so, go! Outis. I've no objection. There's lots to do, I'm sure, about the house. Prometh. Get out! Outis. Well! don't be so cantankerous. Prometh. Woman, away! Outis. I'm going, can't you see; But, mind— Prometh. Adopt invisibility! Duet.—Offenbach. Outis. Why can't you take things somewhat easy, Copying your mother's unassuming ways? Whose constant thought is still to please ye, Love disinterested and above all praise! You, instead, I'm grieved to say—model, model, &c. You, instead, I'm grieved to say—model, model! Model, model—all the day! Prometh. Pray, mother, cease—it's most distressing Thus to interrupted be, and bored beside; Take my advice, without more pressing, Let a very gentle hint your actions guide. Though it's not polite to say—toddle, toddle, &c. Though it's not polite to say—toddle, toddle! Toddle, toddle—right away! Repeat ensemble—Outis dances off, L. 1 E. Prometh. Now, as a fact not generally known, Permit me to observe that—I'm alone. That being the case, it won't cause much surprise, If I'm expected to soliloquize— My speculation! Ah! how well it speeds, As day goes on, and as the night succeeds. Last eve I laboured, thirst and hunger scorning, And finished fifty models ere the morning— Gigantic scheme! sublime! but where's the odds, If I can't animate these lifeless clods? Worse than mere milestones—destitute of sense, Whereas in milestones there's intelligence. Is it for this I waste my time and care, To people all the earth with earthenware; And as a finish to this piece of mockery, To be sole father to a race of crockery! Courage, Prometheus! (post horn without) Ah! what do I see? The Olympian mail car coming straight for me! I know the liveries—yes, and see! two passengers! Enter Outis at wing, with large fork with sausages on it. Outis. For goodness' sake, Prometheus, try these sassengers! Exit Outis L. 1 E. Prometh. What can they want? Ah! they have separated! It seems to interruption I am fated. Enter Mercury, R. 1 E. Mercury. Prometheus, hail! Prometh. (up at table) Well, what's the news with you? Merc. I've just dropt in to ask you how d'ye do? Apollo came with me, he'll soon be here. Outis. (appearing at L. 1 E.) I say, Prometheus, isn't that the beer? Merc. Madam, 'tis I—your humble servant. Outis. Oh! What did he go and call out “hail,” then, so? Exit. Merc. There's Outis out o' sorts—in hand a flask! 'Ow 'tis with her, I think I needn't ask. Outis. (appearing at L. 1 E.) I won't be long! Exit, L. Prometh. Now, may I ask the reason Of your appearance? Merc. Is it out of season? Prometh. Remarkably! I think you've come to spy; It's like you to aspire to play a spy! Of lackey's tricks, no lack is found in you, I'm up to every little plot you brew. Be off! of all your knaveries I'm weary. Merc. (aside) He ne'er shows mercy to a mercenary. (aloud) Pray, why so harsh? (aside) I wonder what's to follow! (red fire at R. 1 E., kept on till the entrance of Outis) Apollo. (without, R. 1 E.) Steady there—woa! Merc. Thank goodness there's Apollo! Enter Apollo, R. 1 E. talking to some one outside. Apollo. (R.) Just ease the girths, but see they're safely tied; (Prometheus at table, stirring plaster in bowl) I think you'd better leave the sun outside. Morning, Prometheus! up, I see, and stirring. (aside to Mercury) Found out yet? Merc. (R. C.) No, the question I'm deferring. He's surly! Prometh. (up at table) Always am—I hate late snoozing. (coming forward, L.) Morning, Apollo! Apollo. Manner's not amoozing! Prometh. Just keep your sun a little further, pray. Those steeds of yours will burn my house some day. Fine animals! Apollo. (crossing to C.) That leader came from Sestos; Stands fire well, and so he counts as best 'os. Paced like a racer in his wildest haste, In fact I may say that he's racer paced. Merc. (R.) He seems obstropolous! Apollo. (C.) No! mild, quite mild. I warrant he'd be driven by a child. Prometh. (L.) How about Phæton? Apollo. Hem! why you see The very day of that catastrophe— Prometh. and Merc. Yes! yes! Enter Outis, L. 1 E.—gets up stage. Apollo. Just e'er the reins I had transferred, Jove said to me, (it's true upon my word) “Apollo,” said he, looking rather blue, “Remember that I told you”— Outis. (coming between Apollo and Prometheus) How d'ye do? (Apollo takes stage over to L.) Prometh. (L. C.) A sad hiatus; what a dreadful sell! Merc. (R.) I hate a story as don't finish well. Trio.—Air, “Home Sweet Home.” Prometh. Were I as wise as Pallas is P'raps I might find, Of that recital What's left behind. Vain all endeavouring, Fancy may roam, But sans intelligence Soon wanders home! Air, “Original Schottishe.” Outis. Pray for breakfast, sirs, what may I have the pleasure To prepare? I will unfold my larder's treasure; Trust me, you shall have the fullest measure Of a Titan's hospita-li-tie! Pray take a sophy, tea and coffee ready are, With chops, steaks, kidneys, eggs, and ham, well fed ye are, Nectar and Ambrosia, till you unsteady are, Only give your orders if you please, to me. (repeat ensemble, Mercury and Apollo joining in —harmonized—at end Mercury, Apollo, and Outis up stage) Prometh. (aside) Now might I do it pat, while he is staying, His visit's àpropos, so's his delaying, While he is for the next long stage preparing, I'll be at hand to do a deed of daring. (taking a staff from wing, L.) This staff I'll thrust within the blazing wheel, And from its spokes the vital spark I'll steal; With this I will enlighten my clay folks, That fire must make them speak, which comes from spokes. Apollo. (coming down R.) Well, I must go. Outis. (L. C.) Oh! do join our symposia. I've got a case of superfine ambrosia! As for the nectar—how 'twould please your throttle, I've had it now myself, three weeks in bottle. Merc. (R. C.) What, you keep nectar? Apollo. Why I thought— Outis. You see It's not the genuine commodity. We hav'nt got the capital to spare, It's only chemicals got up with care! With demi-gods you'd not expect to see A costly breakfast for a deity. (dear tea) Apollo. My car! all right. (aside to Mercury) His temper is the deuce; To question now I see would be no use Merc. & Apollo. Farewell, farewell! (red fire at R. 1 E.) Prometh. (crossing over to R.) I'll see you to the door. Apollo. Thank you, don't trouble. Best not venture more. Merc. Oh, mind the flames! Outis. Prometheus! Merc. What's he doing? Apollo. Good gracious! this foolhardiness is ruin. (Prometheus stands in Apollo's way—they start back amazed) Prometh. Excuse me if I venture to make free, I've stood your twaddling, now you hear me. You've come to pry and penetrate my plan— In one word hear the truth—my project's, Man! You've overlooked this grandest of all facts, Prometheus always thinks before he acts. I long have sought in vain to light my clay, And you, Apollo, have supplied the way. Thus, thus I doff the mask, my friends, before ye, And brave your hottest flames like Buonecore. (hurried music—Prometheus rushes out, R. 1 E., and returns with fire on staff, he touches the models and ignites coloured fires on pedestals— the models run off carrying pedestals, &c., with them—Prometheus, Mercury, Outis, and Apollo come forward) Concerted Piece.—“Post Horn Galop.” Apollo. Goodness gracious, goodness gracious! Here's a state of revolution. Merc. Fancy turning contumacious. To our plots here's fine conclusion, Prometh. Think you that I care for you, sir, Though you're mighty highty tighty! Outis. All this comes, my words are true, sir, From being flighty, flighty. Prometh. Victory! I've worked my plan. Merc. You've made, my friend, a precious blunder. Apollo. I must keep my eye on man. Outis. What is he, I wonder? (repeat first part ensemble—galop from opposite corners round stage and all off, R. 1 E.)

Scene Third. —Reception Room in Olympus. (4th groove) —Slow Music to open Scene.—Flourish to bring on Jove, R.—Throne, (1st groove) L. Jove. Apollo not returned? It's getting late, And almost time for us to sit in state. Where are my ministers? and where the Graces? They'd best be quick, and get into their places, Or I'll know— Juno. (entering, R. H.) Eh! what's that? pray what will you know? Jove. Nothing at all, my love—my august Juno! Juno. (crossing, L.) Oh, bother! that'll do; there, take your seat, And I'll sit next to you, by way of treat. Jove. My dear! I promised Venus— Juno. I don't care; If I like, sir, I shall sit anywhere. Jove. Of course! (sighs) Juno. Of course! and here my power to prove, As lawful Queen, I take my seat by Jove! Jove. Don't swear, my dear! (they sit on throne) Juno. Eh! What? Jove. I—I said, Don't swear. Juno. I didn't swear; I swear I didn't. There! Jove. Hush! here's the Court! Music.—Enter Venus, R. 1 E.—Jove rises and goes to her. Ah, Venus! how d'ye do? Venus. I'm pretty well! Jove. (R. C.) Well, you are pretty, too! You're lovely! Venus. (L. C.) Sire! you praise too much, methinks. Juno. (L., rising, and going to Jove) Would you encourage that audacious minx? Jove. My love! Juno. Your love! of that I'll be abater, My hate is strong. In fact, I'm glad I hate her. Thank goodness! here's her husband. (they sit on throne.—Music, “Village Blacksmith.”) Enter Vulcan, R. U. E.—Comes down R.—Venus near throne. Vulcan. Now, where's Venus Venus. Here, darling! Ugh! Juno. There; you can sit between us. (Venus sits on throne between Jove and Juno.— Music, “British Grenadier.”) Enter Mars, R. 1 E. Mars. (R.) Your most obedient, Jove. (Vulcan up stage, R.) Venus. (rises and comes forward, L. C.) Mars, how d'ye do? Why, where have you been? Mars. Looking after you. Venus. Why, hav'nt you been cutting throats and fighting? Mars. My dear, that prospect's not at all inviting. No! I've been (when not looking, love, for you) Doing my usual Fortnightly Review. It's easy and it's dignified, I shirk Much roughing it—Bellona does the work. I'm great at mess-time though—my lucubrations Would make you marvel, when I've 'ad my rations; But camping out's detestable! you see, With my health, damp tent bedsteads don't agree. It doesn't strike me that the thought's extatic— May be romantic, but it's more rheumatic! Venus. You wear a sword, dear? Mars. Which I never wield. Venus. D'ye never sleep upon the “tented field?” Vulcan. (down between them) A couch that's made 'midst buttercups, he's shy on. The verdant sward, how could a dandy lie on? Mars. (R.) Don't be severe, Smith! Vulcan. (R. C.) Won't I! You shall see. Last Tuesday, sir, you kissed my Mrs. V. Venus. (L. C.) Under the misletoe—it's very jolly! Vulcan. A piece of misletoe! a piece of 'olly! (to Mars) You must have found your last campaign a hard un; And unproductive? Mars. There, I beg your pardon! You know I don't fight! Vulcan. That you don't, you craven— Mars. I'll pluck a crow with you. Vulcan. (striking attitude) A crow! You're ravin! Mars. Why do you strike that attitude? Vulcan. You'll see, 'Tis but the prelude to my striking thee. You mind your p's and q's. You most unruly are. (retires up) Mars. My p's and q's, that's language most peculiar! (to Venus) I'm gentle, 'cos I don't wish to alarm ye. Coarse party! don't at all admire the Army; I ne'er address him, but his dander up is, And he unfeelingly alludes to puppies. With me, his temper always is the same. Unhappy cripple! yes! toujours le maim! Jove. There, don't go on like that! Venus. Minerva's here. Music—enter Minerva, R. 1 E. (aside) The fright! (aloud) How lovely you do look, my dear! Juno. Humbug! Miner. What's that? Remember pray, my dears, All slang American, offends my ears. Madam, I'm not a Juno nor a Venus. Juno. D'you know, there is some difference between us? Miner. I hate a pun, a quibble, or a jest; Let conversation in plain clothes be dressed. You jeer at Pallas 'cos she's strict and staid. With all your railing you'll need Pallas' aid! Venus. Poor dear old Pallas! Miner. Cease your fun, my dears, There's not much difference in our length of years. Vulcan. (coming forward) Haw! Haw! Venus. Do stop. Mars. Yes do. Vulcan. You ugly wretch! Mars. Ugly! Jove. Well, so, so! Juno. Even that's a stretch. Mars. What, don't you think me handsome? Juno. No, not very You've got red hair! Venus, Well that's hair red itary. A puerile objection! see, his smile. Mars. A greaseful compliment that's not pure ile. Venus. Poor Mars, I feel for you, well never mind, To imperfections love is ever blind, You know my heart is true, although you're plain. Mars. Then hear me swear, dear. Vulcan. (interferes) Here we are again! (Mars Venus and Vulcan retire up) Jove. Silence a moment, e'er our levee end, The Fates and Furies promised to attend, And here they come, arriving in a rally. Mars. (confidentially to Audience—down R.) They're introduced, you'll understand, as Ballet. (Ballet—Characteristic dance of the Fates and Furies, at conclusion, loud noise, R. U. E.) Venus. What's that I wonder? Goodness, there's a row, Mars do step out and see what's happened now. Jove. What a conclusion to a scene of amor As a Scotch observation “unde clamor.” Neptune. (outside R.) Shiver my timbers, split my capstan bars! Juno. (on Throne) Good gracious! Neptune. Venus. (L.) Noisiest of tars. Music.—“Bay of Biscay.”—Enter Neptune R. U. E. and down, C. Neptune. (C.) Odds timbers, clewlines, bowlines, sheets, and stays, (Minerva turns up) I never saw the like in my born days, The Throne's in danger, danger, do ye hear? All. Hear! hear! Jove. (on Throne L.) I say. my fine old friend, what cheer? Juno. There, drop it, Neptune, go back to your ocean, This dreadful railing breeds such low commotion. Mars. (R.) In future, Neptune, to avoid such scenes, Refer your matters to your own marines; I think you might have left that (the Trident) had you tried, There's an umbrella stand, you know, outside. Neptune. (C.) I say, Prometheus, all you molly-coddles Has found some means to vivify his models; From hour to hour they grow like Hydra's heads, We'll all be murdered in our ocean beds. All. Explain! explain! Neptune. Oh, easy as you please! A monstrous fleet is sailing on my seas, With a clay captain and a porcelain mate, Lieutenants, middies, cabins, berths of state, Aping me, Neptune, monarch of the ocean; Offering clay merit—what they call promotion. Well! just as I was sitting with my barber, Down tumbled their best bower in my arbour; And when I tried the rascals' course to vary— All. You blew them overboard? Neptune. No, quite contr?ry. Though dark as pitch, they laughed at all my rumpus, And boxed— Jove. Your ears? Neptune. No! what they called a compass. My storms all fail, my Tritons will be slaves, For what he calls Britannia rules my waves. Apollo. (rushing in, R. U. E., and down, C., to Jove.) Room, room within! Vengeance, great Jove, I pray; Let not this Titan quench the light of day. Prometheus— Jove. What, again? Apollo. Has dared to run His stick into the middle of my sun. All. Into your son? Jove. What! Phaëton? All. Oh, no! My S-U-N—the sun. All. Oh, here's a go! Concerted piece.—Air, “We're English, too,” from translation of “Bataclan,” by W. Brough. We're injured, too, I'm injured, too, We all alike are injured, too, &c., &c. His rudeness is too much to bear: Fancy insulting the chair. I'm injured, too, &c., &c. Enter Diana and Mercury with Prometheus, R. U. E., down C.—Neptune and Apollo by throne, L. All. Ha! ha! ho! ho! ho! ho! ha! ha! he! he! Merc. (L. C.) He! he! of course it is. (gets to L. corner) Prometh. (R. C.) Oh, yes, it's me! Excuse the grammar. Jove. (on throne) So we've got you, eh? Prometh. Oh, no! I took Olympus on my way. I've just looked in. Jove. Well, just look out! Mars. (R.) That's good. Jove. Your insolence too long, sir, we have stood. Neptune. You young loblolly-boy, I just should like To knock your brains out with a marlinspike. Why, darn your impudence? Prometh. (C.) There, stop your clatter. With all your darning you'll not mend the matter. Neptune. Oh, Jove, pray punish this young chap's presumin'. Prometh. Shall a brave old tar be pitched into by two-men? Diana. (R. C.) I'd make him suffer if the chance were mine. Prometh. I make light of your threats, they're all moonshine. Diana. All moonshine! oh, with very rage I smother! (goes up) Prometh. And that you owe, ma'am, to the sun, your brother. Vulcan. Let's shut him up. Prometh. D'ye think you could succeed? Of course, you always were my friend in-kneed. Apollo. (L. C.) Insolent Titan! Jove I claim protection. Prometh. As glass of fashion you may cast reflection. Venus. (R.) The saucy wretch! Prometh. Ah, Madam Venus. sulkin'? There, go to Mars; he'll please you after Vulcan. Mars. (R. corner) Villain! Prometh. There, stop! your face, so broad and spacious, Seems like a sort of writ of fiery facias. Bosh! Some may think, because you long have blustered, You'd give them pepper when your force is mustered. I know you well, you brawling, drinking Trinculo! Ask Vulcan of your late escape “a vinculo.” Merc. (L. corner) All seem to have their whack; then why not I? (goes up to Prometheus, C.) Prometh. My dear deceptive friend, I'll let you lie. (Mercury goes back to L. corner) Minerva. (coming down R. of Prometheus) Hear Wisdom's voice, young man. Prometh. Oh, cease! pray do! I hate to hear you babble, old Bas Bleu. (Minerva retires up) Enter Outis, R. U. E., down C., L. of Prometheus. Outis. (L. C.) Lawks! mercy! Jove! Neptune. Hallo! what cheer, my hearty? Jove. Who's this exhilarated female party? Prometh. (R. C.) My mother, Jove. Outis. Prometheus, if you knew, The trouble that I've had to get to you. Merc. (L. corner) I brought her, and her bandbox; yes, I staid for it. Outis. And so you ought, sir, seeing that I paid for it. He wouldn't take me gratis, dear, not he, Though in the greatest of anxiety, So I agreed; a shilling out I drew, My only one, exclaiming “Voila tout.” Jove. (on throne) Madam, retire; we wish to spare your ears The prisoner's sentence. (Outis collapses) Prometh. Mother, dry your tears. Outis. One day, great Jove; just to collect his powers. Jove. No; not a minute—now the chance is ours. Take him away. (two Gods seize him) His sentence is deferred Prometh. I'll have a reckoning for this, take my word. Outis. A reckoning now you're 'ad up. How I sigh for you! I'll do— All. What? Outis. Anything, my dear, but die for you. Never say die—hurray! Jove. Just seize that woman! Outis. Woman, indeed! I do like that uncooman. Jove. You're now my slave, and I've a strong suspicion, You'll find, my man, you'll miss your manumission. Prometh. Ha! ha! Outis. Ha! ha! (extravagantly) Jove. Ah! you do well to laugh. Outis. We do not care a straw, sir, for your chaff! Jove. (rises and comes forward) The sitting's up. Friends, to our council room; Apollo shall decide the villain's doom. (all come forward to sing finale to Scene Third) Mar., Venus, Vul, 2 Gods, Prom., Out., Apol., Jov., Jun., Mer., R. L. Concerted Piece—Air, “Bondebryllup” (“Bring home the Bride”) Prometh. Stop where you are! you'll find I've gone too far, There's no receding—nor impeding! Apollo. Jove, hear me sue! behold me kneel to you. Shall the sun thus be done by a low proceeding? Chorus. Jove, protect our dignity! Thus insulted shall we be? Shall we tamely look on so, And see ourselves derided? No! No, no, no, &c. Prometh. with Chorus. Sue and pray, 'tis all the same, Your new king's protection claim, But you'll find I've gone too far— Therefore, I'll observe, Ha! ha! Ha! ha! &c. (at the end of Concerted Piece, all draw up stage to be closed in on picture—Prometheus held by two Gods, C.—Outis entreating, L. C.—Vulcan, R. C., and Mars, R., threatening—Apollo, L. C., Jove, Juno, Mercury, R.—other Gods at back—Venus, R., on the left of Mars)

Scene Fourth. —The Palace of the Sun (1st grooves) Music.—Enter Apollo, L., in thought. Apollo. 'Tis very well! but if he should—he might! Because—why not?—if otherwise—all right: But no—exactly—not at all—I can— Impossible!—I have it—that's my plan. (to audience) After this lucid course of argument, Of course you all will guess why here I'm sent. Prometheus's game is played—that worst of men Is in a den—a wretched denizen. By Jove remanded till I can suggest Enter Venus, unobserved, L. 1 E. A punishment that suits his crime the best. I'm at my wit's end! Venus. (touching him) You'd not far to go. Apollo. Venus! how could you start a fellah so? Venus. Well, have you thought of anything? Apollo. Of course; I mean to tie him on a bare-backed horse. Venus. Pooh! we've all seen that long ago; it takes At Astley's, dear, with the extensive rakes. His men can save him too. Apollo. He's not to die, But miserably linger. Venus. Cruelty! But now to business, Phœbus—I've a plan! To please, to plague, in short, to do for man. A healing balm to wound—a curse to bless him— A truth to gull—a comfort to distress him; To bring him all his joys and all his fears, To set him and his fellows by the ears, To make the greybeard dote—the youthful sad— Turn wisdom foolishness, drive reason mad: To sway the world, and nations' hearts to wring, To be— Apollo. In short— Venus. A woman is the thing. Apollo. First rate—I'm off to Jove! Venus. I'll go with you. Vulcan's the very man the thing to do. Apollo. She'll play the deuce of course? Venus. The very thing. I'm off—farewell! (going, R.) Apollo. Stop! we forgot to sing. Duet.—Air, “I would I were a Bird.” (1st part only) Apollo. From what has just occurred, I think you'll plainly see, With poor Prometheus now, 'Twill soon be all U P; I'm off, like any bird, To give the cue to Jove, And he, believe my word, The plan will much approve. First part of “Guards' Waltz.” Venus. I would I were a bird, Tho' 'tis no use to pray; And wings I think at times would be, Absurdly in a woman's way. I think upon my word, It is not more outrè, To wish to be a daisy, Which shuts up at close of day. (repeat ensemble—harmonized, and waltz off, R.— hurried Music) Enter Prometheus, L. Prometh. Escaped at length! most cleverly eluded, I got out smartly, as the other crew did. What will be done with me? I dare say Jove, Who's rather anxious for his throne above, Will seek revenge on his rebellious slavey; Shut in some cave, he'll make me cry peccavi. Or, as he cannot touch my life, will try And make existence one long misery. Song.—Air, “Constantinople.” My friends above are all elate, Maliciously diverted, To see me in my fallen state, By all alike deserted. Too proud to make a meek appeal, I still support my Titan claim, Which they heed no more than if I, From Constantinople came— Constantinople, etc., It counts the same. Their jeers and taunts can little move, A soul so great as this is; But 'tis the faithlessness of Jove, And his revengeful missis! Since e'er his usurpation, we Lived on a footing quite the same; No wonder now that I, his being Constant to no pal, blame Constant to no pal, &c., It's that I blame. What will become of me. I'd like to know? Oh! for some friendly help! (stage dark—Sun-head in flat, illuminated) Sun. Hallo! Prometh. Hallo! Good gracious, who are you? Why, see, he winks; I beg your pardon, are you Stodare's Sphinx? Sun. No, I'm an oracle! Prometh. What a colossus! You look more like the famed Anthropoglossus. But since you're such a swell, perhaps you would'nt Mind telling me my fortune! Sun. No, I should'nt. Jove has designed your overthrow! Prometh. Oh, goodness! Sun. Don't interrupt me. Prometh. Pardon, pray, my rudeness. Sun. He's had a box constructed, which contains Life's horrors, sorrows, evils, aches, and pains. This box as dowry to your wife he gives. Prometh. I have no wife. Sun. 'Tis but this hour she lives— Vulcan has made her! Prometh. Here's a pretty pass! Sun. One thing should recommend her—she's got brass; Out of that metal she was fabricated. Prometh. To this belle metal, then, it seems I'm mated. Sun. Too true—but mind that box. Apollo. (outside, L.) He's gone! hallo! Prometh. Apollo's voice! I'd best be off. Sun. No go, I fear; but, run! perhaps my dread is vain; At all events, my friend, we'll meet again. (Sun-head disappears.—Lights up.—Prometheus exits, R.) Enter Apollo and Venus, L. Apollo. (R.) I heard his voice this way! Venus. (L., aside) Yes, so did I! I won't tell, but the fugitive I spy. Poor fellow! he's so handsome; 'twould be shame Just for revenge to spoil his little game. Apollo. He must be here about! Yes! Venus. What? Apollo. (as Captain O'Scuttle, crossing to L.) Ha! (crossing back to R.) No! Venus. Good gracious, Phœbus! pray don't bellow so. Apollo. Bellow, d'ye call it; prettiest of dears, That bawling's called the music of the spheres! Venus. That's not so bad for you. Apollo. (looking R.) What do I see! Say, do my eyes deceive my ear-sight! He! They nose, them face, that clothes! It must be so; Follow me quick! Hallo! Stop thief! Hallo! Venus. (detaining him) They nose, that eyes, those face! how wild you look. Apollo. For which you'll blame—Artemus Ward, his book. (Exeunt, R.) Enter Outis, L. Outis. This sort of woe's too terrible to last; I don't move much, and yet I'm going fast. Once I was plump and stout, and full in feature, Almost as fat as pork, alas! poor creature! Now, what a different case; what woful plight; I shouldn't wonder if my hair's turned white. (looks) No; still the same bright thing it was. Alas! Matters have come now to a pretty pass. I'm out upon parole, they don't mind me; They've only seized upon Prometheus; he Is sternly waiting for his doom to-day. What will they do with me, I wonder, pray? P'raps put me up for marriage! What's the odds! There'll be some competition 'mongst the gods! Song.—Air, “Tootle tum tay.” Please to look on these charms manifold; Not too bold, not too old, For not yet forty summers I've told, And my hair is a long way from grey! In my form, as I gracefully swerve, Pray, observe, what a curve, Elasticity, firmness, and nerve. Tootle tum, &c. Although, I'm not strictly perfection, No god need despise the connection. Tootle tum, &c. The deities' hearts I shall vex, I expects, like my sex, I may fascinate Jupiter Rex; For I hear, that he's given that way. And who knows, but great Juno may see, Even me, cap-a-pie, In the robes of her late majesty. Tootle tum, &c. Though I vowed I'd ne'er wed any day, now, A New Royalty's quite in my way, now! Tootle tum, &c. Ha! Jove approaches—yes, and all the Court; Down, trembling flutterer, and look out for sport. Enter Jove and Court, R.—Apollo, Mercury and Neptune get over, L.—Jove, R. C.—Juno, L. C.—Mars, Venus and Minerva, R. Jove. (R. C.) Superb idea! by my crown a bright 'un! We'll cook the goose of this loose-fish, this Titan! Apollo, your'e a trump—three cheers for Sol, oh! (All give three loud cheers) Mars. (R. corner) That's not so bad, Apollo! Juno. (L. C.) We've got no time for shouting, now, Outis. (L.) Great Jove! (aside) P'raps, even now, I may his mercy move. Jove. What's this? Repulsive hag! Which! What! Outis. Good gracious! Juno. This woman's conduct here is most audacious! Seize her! (Neptune, who is on the L. of Juno, makes a movement as if about to lay hold of her) Outis. Seize me! just try and you will rue it! A seizure, yes! I think I sees yer do it! (crosses, C., to Juno) Mercy, great Jove, see how I kneel to thee! You'll call me hag; behold this hag on knee! Spare my dear son! (kneeling) Jove. To judge, in vain you tries. Apollo. (L. corner) You've got your son, ma'am, too much in your eyes. Outis. Ah! say some kind word in extenuation; And give your pal, some sort of palliation. Respect my cries and tears! Jove. Oh, those I'm weary on! A cry or tear of grief is no criterion! Outis. Refused! rejected! Apollo. Can there be a doubt? Outis. Farewell, my blissful visions— Jove. There—get out! Outis. Get out! Oh! (collapses—Minerva takes her a little way up stage, trying to restore her) Jove. Now, while that old party's sulkin', Just step and send a telegram to Vulcan. Merc. (L.) He's here! Enter Vulcan, with a Cyclops bearing a large basket, with no bottom to it, L. Jove. Now, Vulcan, is the task completed? You've had some hard work, and look rather heated. Vulcan. It's done. I think you'll own I'm pretty quick. l'll introduce the lady in a trick. You see there's nothing in the basket? (puts basket over trap, C.) All. Yes. Vulcan. Cyclops, get in. (he does so) Now all your smiles repress. (business of Stodare's Indian Basket Feat) Mars, lend your sword. (crossing to Mars, R.) Now, if you please, look out. Have you got down the trap? (to Cyclops) Cyclops. No, I'm too stout. I'm gone now. (goes down trap—chord) Vulcan. Then this wondrous deed observe. (stabbing basket—chord) Outis. The murdering wretch! Oh, hasn't he a nerve! (faints, and is carried off, R., by Minerva, who returns) All. Prodigious! Wonderful! (short hurry, and Pandora rises through basket up trap, C.) Jove. (R. C.) A charming creature! Venus. (R.) So! so! Miner. (R.) There's no expression in a feature! Juno. (L. C.) Too short! Mercury. Too tall! Apollo. (L.) Fine eyes, hair not amiss! Jove. Truce to your sneers and gibes, I say; drop this. I hereby give command that every goddess, Who owns a charm that's fit for human bodies, If they have anything, be quick in giving, And let this maid eclipse all after living. First for her title. Mars. (R.) Silence in the court! Jove. This maiden's claim we settle to support. Mars. Si-lence! Jove. An awful voice—a downright crusher. Hush! Mars. 'Tis my business, sir, as I'm a husher. Jove. Well, hear me swear by Styx, I grant her fame, By giving her a most expressive name, And so I call her— Mars. Silence for a floorer! Jove. Call her the model woman, and Pandora. (cheers by All) And now, Pandora, do not think me grudging, When I inform you, you must now be trudging. First take this box, it isn't heavy, feel it; Don't let a soul beg, borrow it, or steal it; Into your husband's hands place it alone, He'll open it himself. Juno. (melodramatically) Is't done? Jove. (melodramatically) 'Tis done. Mars. Say, may I have the pleasure to escort? Apollo. No. May I, madam? Mars. Sir! Pooh, that's your sort! Vulcan. Let me. Neptune. No! Brother Vulcan, you're too slow. I'll take the jolly little craft in tow. Jove. Now cease at once this flow of eloquence, Mercury will conduct the maid from hence. Mars. Confound the puppy! Mercury. (crossing to Pandora Hem! Jove. Well dear, good bye. Venus. We shall expect to see you in the sky. Juno. We'll call and visit you, of course, my dear. Mars. Don't be surprised to see me re-appear. Apollo. (and all the other gods) And me, and me, &c. Jove. That style urbane will be his bane I see, Here, Mercury, that box, Pandora's dowry. Minerva. (R.) (to Mercury, who goes off R. with Pandora taking no notice of what Minerva says) Take an umbrella, Merky, it looks show'ry. Exit R. offended at Mercury's indifference Jove. (aside) It holds all evils in that little space, Doom and destruction to the human race, Prometheus, if he opens it is lost, And all his projects to the winds are tossed. This beats Pandora, betterer and betterer, Revenge, ha! ha! he! he! ho! ho! etcetera. Chorus—“Kafoozleum.” Jove. Oh Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Jerusalem, She'll bamboozle 'em. Chorus Fol de rol de rido. Jove. If my scheme's of any worth. From the moment of her birth, She will play the deuce on earth, Chorus. Fol de rol de rido. Apollo. Though old as Methusalem, &c. She'll manage to bamboozle 'em, Chorus. Fol de rol de rido. Apollo. Be they young or be they grey, She with them the deuce will play, So I've only got to say, All. Fal de rol de rido. (Short dance and all of, R. 1 E. leaving Mars and Venus on, who continue dance and off, R.)

Scene Fifth. —Rocky shore and crags of Caucasus— working waters down to back of 1st grooves—set rock— piece, L., with Prometheus discovered chained to it— vulture hanging over him—working sun in flats, R.— sunset. Music.—“On Yonder Rock Reclining.” Prometh. On this hard rock reclining, A sad and suffering form behold, Doomed to perpetual pining, Thro' rain and heat and cold. Fixed firm and fast, I hardly can say for good you know; Seeing as how I must suffer here, When stormy winds do blow.—oh! (change to “One Horse Shay”) I feel so like Mazeppa, When he's tied upon his stepper, The “fiery untamed steed,” as the playbills say; But the creature as we know, Tho' they make him caper so, Is less fitted for a hero than a One horse shay. Prometheus It's getting rather painful, this position Not being an acrobatic exhibition. Fancy being fixed here for infinity, Thus cragged so picturesquely by the sea. Ha! horrid bird! with fear my limbs all shiver. See! how he comes and lights upon my liver. I say get out! (Vulture flies off) Thank you, obliging vulture! It's too much to be eaten e'er sepulture. (sun sinks) There goes the sun; in spite of what he said His promise must have slipped out of his head. (sings) “Shades of evening close not o'er us,” Sun. (re-appearing) Tol de riddle ol de loll loll lay. Prometh. What, old friend, back again; that's very queer, How do you manage thus to re-appear? Sun. It's a stage trick. (eyes work) Prometh. Why are your eyes thus rolling? Sun. I grieve to see you lying like Tom Bowling, Quite a sheer hulk. Prometh. You know I'm fixed for ever. Sun. What a conclusion for a chap so clever! Wait till your wife comes, she will set you free. Prometh. The only time she'll give me liberty. Sun. Remember, mind, don't ope that box. Prometh. All right. How good to have a friend at court. Sun. Good night! Prometh. What! must you go? Your shades pray don't close o'er us; Or if you must, at least assist as chorus. Air, “Midas.” Prometheus Since you mean to sink for good, sir, Pray don't send your dews too soon; I should thank you if you would, sir, Send your substitute, the moon. Prometh., Sun. Fol de riddle lol, &c., &c. (Sun sinks) Enter Mercury, Pandora, and Outis, R. 1 E. Outis. Step softly, dear Pandora! Should he sleep, At his perfections you can take a peep. Here is a precious state of things for he, Once brought up in the lux of lapsury! Pando. I feel so bashful. Outis. Well, perhaps you do; I used to feel so, dear, when young as you. Merc. Well, as I've seen you now so far, I'll go. Here is your box. Outis. (takes box) Ha! let me see. Prometh. Hallo! That is the box I'm warned against, no doubt, And that's my spouse to be when I get out. Merc. Ha! see he wakes! allow me, dear—Pandora! (introducing) Prometheus Know each other. Prometh. I'm before her; Thanks to a friendly hint received, I know Precisely all the circumstances. Outis. Oh! If I could only find out what's in here. Something remarkable, I've an idea. Pandora, love! (Pandora goes to her) Merc. (to Prometheus) So here you're fast, my friend. I guessed how your absurdities would end. Prometh. They've ended, have they? Merc. Rather; I suppose Your punishment won't have so short a close, For thirty thousand years you're fixed up here. Prometh. (L.) And is that all they'll do to me, my dear? (as in “Arrah na Pogue”) Merc. (L.) All—all? it's quite enough, I think, to try, Even a Titan's courage. Outis. (R.) Hallo! Why, It's not locked after all—here goes—oh my! (hurried music—thunder, &c.—stage dark—Outis faints—Pandora runs off—Enter all the Characters, R. 1 E.) Outis. Murder! help! murder! Jove. (R. C.) So my scheme's succeeded. Prometh. Yet all your ingenuity was needed. All. (R.) We are avenged! Prometh. Yes, I must own you've won. Apollo (R.) You'll pay back what you borrowed from the Sun— And for this trick, which ruins all mythology, I think you owe Apollo an apolo-gy. Prometh. Impossible! you see mankind has gained A principle, from you, my friend, obtained, Which makes them free for ever. Jove. But you know They've got a thousand evils now en dôt. Prometh. Too true! all's lost! I'm beaten and give in. Outis. Which throwing up the sponge, dear, is a sin! All. Yield, Titan bold! Prometh. Yes, yes, I yield! Hope. (rising, C.—short hurry) Not so, There's still a hope left. Jove. (R. C.) Who are you? All. (R.) Hallo! Hope. (C.) Why I am Hope! You thought your scheme you'd worked, But at the bottom of that box I lurked. Apollo. What 'mongst the ills of man? Jove. A horrid sell! Outis. Why then you've left the bottom of your well. Hope. Though you've infested all mankind with pains, Woes, sorrows, evils, yet still hope remains. To hope he'll look when troubled clouds may lower, And hope will always soothe his latest hour. Prometheus, throw your chains away. There, see, While hope is by him—man is ever free. (Prometheus throws off chains and comes forward C., Hope goes on rock) Jove. (L. C.) Well, then it seems I'm beaten after all, So here I will your punishment recall. I give you freedom now with cordiality, And greet your liberty— Outis. With Jovi-ality. (cheers) Prometh. (to Audience) And say now what can poor Prometheus do, But trust to hope and still appeal to you? You are the only arbiters of fate, You weigh the merits of our little state. We still must hope your favours to obtain, We, who have never sued to you in vain. Prometheus claims from you a kind excuse For all this folly—sure you'll not refuse? Deal gently with his case—accept his cause, And let your verdict kindly be applause. Finale.—Air, “Isn't it a Pullback.” Prometh. And now our piece is ended For fun alone intended, If 'tis by you commended, Reward we get in full back Of joys besides a full whack, And nothing like a pull back. Ho, hi, ho, joys at its prime oh! Oh, hi, ho, &c. At Christmas time oh! Oh, hi, ho, &c. Air, “The Harp that once through Tara's Halls.” Chorus. Cheer us now and on our play With lenient eyes look down, Prometheus lives if you but smile, He dies if you should frown. Oh! bid him live and wreath around His brow success's crown. (walk round—dance) Hope on rock. Prometheus. Outis. Juno. Minerva. Jove. Vulcan. Neptune. Venus. Apollo. Mars. Mercury. R. L. (Tableau.) Curtain.
